Utilize strong cryptographic techniques and protocols to prevent eavesdropping on network communications.

Deploy mechanisms to protect the confidentiality of information related to operational processes, facility locations, device configurations, programs, or databases that may have information that can be used to infer organizational trade-secrets, recipes,

Have alternative methods to support communication requirements during communication failures and data integrity attacks. (Citation: National Institute of Standards and Technology April 2013) (Citation: Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency)
Redundancy could be provided for both critical ICS devices and services, such as back-up devices or hot-standbys.

Require the authentication of devices and software processes where appropriate. Devices that connect remotely to other systems should require strong authentication to prevent spoofing of communications. Furthermore, software processes should also require

Configure hosts and devices to use static network configurations when possible, protocols that require dynamic discovery/addressing (e.g., ARP, DHCP, DNS) can be used to manipulate network message forwarding and enable various AiTM attacks. This mitigatio
Utilize watchdog timers to ensure devices can quickly detect whether a system is unresponsive.
This type of attack technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventative controls since it is based on the abuse of system features.
Implement a supply chain management program, including policies and procedures to ensure all devices and components originate from a trusted supplier and are tested to verify their integrity.

Devices and programs designed to interact with control system parameters should validate the format and content of all user inputs and actions to ensure the values are within intended operational ranges. These values should be evaluated and further enforc
This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.
Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use security identifier (SID) Filtering, etc.
Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.
Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.
Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.
A threat intelligence program helps an organization generate their own threat intelligence information and track trends to inform defensive priorities to mitigate risk.
Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.
Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.
Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.
Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.
Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.
Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.
Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  In industrial control environments, network intrusion prevention should be configured so it will not disrupt protocols and communications responsible for real-time functions relat

Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  Within industrial control environments assets such as low-level controllers, workstations,
Block users or groups from installing or using unapproved hardware on systems, including USB devices.

ATT&CK Mitigation Name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
ATT&CK Mitigation Description: Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.
Configure features related to account use like login attempt lockouts, specific login times, etc.

Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.   Perform inline allow/denylisting of network messages based on the application layer (OSI Layer 7)
Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.
Protect sensitive data-at-rest with strong encryption.

ATT&CK Mitigation Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
ATT&CK Mitigation Description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.
Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.
Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.

Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses. Perform periodic integrity checks of the device to validate the correctness of the firmware, software, programs, and config
Restrict the execution of code to a virtual environment on or in-transit to an endpoint system.

Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  Within industrial control environments, antivirus/antimalware installations should be limited to assets that are not involved in critical or real-time operations. To minimize the impact to system
Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.
Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk. Software updates may need to be scheduled around operational down times.

Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated with how the software operates.

Install security updates in response to discovered vulnerabilities.  Purchase devices with a vendor and/or mobile carrier commitment to provide security updates in a prompt manner for a set period of time.  Decommission devices that will no longer receive
Enable remote attestation capabilities when available (such as Android SafetyNet or Samsung Knox TIMA Attestation) and prohibit devices that fail the attestation from accessing enterprise resources.

On devices that provide the capability to unlock the bootloader (hence allowing any operating system code to be flashed onto the device), perform periodic checks to ensure that the bootloader is locked.
Ensure that Android devices being used include and enable the Verified Boot capability, which cryptographically ensures the integrity of the system partition.

New mobile operating system versions bring not only patches against discovered vulnerabilities but also often bring security architecture improvements that provide resilience against potential vulnerabilities or weaknesses that have not yet been discovere

Describes any guidance or training given to users to set particular configuration settings or avoid specific potentially risky behaviors.
An enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM), system can be used to provision policies to mobile devices to control aspects of their allowed behavior.
This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.

Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.
Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.
Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.
A threat intelligence program helps an organization generate their own threat intelligence information and track trends to inform defensive priorities to mitigate risk.
Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.
Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.
Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.
Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.

Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.
Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.
Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.
Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.
Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.

Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.
Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.
Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.
Block users or groups from installing or using unapproved hardware on systems, including USB devices.

ATT&CK Mitigation Name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
ATT&CK Mitigation Description: Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.
Configure features related to account use like login attempt lockouts, specific login times, etc.
Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.
Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.
Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.
Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.
Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.

ATT&CK Mitigation Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
ATT&CK Mitigation Description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.
Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.

Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.
Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.
Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.
Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.
Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.
Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.
Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.
Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.
Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.
Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.
Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.
This category is to associate techniques that mitigation might increase risk of compromise and therefore mitigation is not recommended.
This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.(Citation: PurpleSec Data Loss Prevention)
Mobile security products, such as Mobile Threat Defense (MTD), offer various device-based mitigations against certain behaviors.
Present deceptive information about systems, data, processes, and users. Monitor uses or search for presence of that information.
Maintain a distinct subsystem or a set of components specifically designed to be the target of malicious attacks for detecting, deflecting, and analyzing such attacks.
Use a dynamic execution environment to handle potentially harmful incoming data.
Use a factitious system or resource to decoy adversary attacks away from operational resources, to increase the adversary’s workload, or to observe adversary activities.
Validate the provenance of system components.
Provide multiple distinct supply chains for system components.
Simulate adversary activities to test the effectiveness of system protections and detection mechanisms.

ATT&CK Mitigation Name: Dynamically Restrict Traffic or Isolate Resources
ATT&CK Mitigation Description: Dynamically reconfigure networks to restrict network traffic or isolate resources.
Use virtualization to create a controlled execution environment, which is expunged after execution terminates.
Analyze files and data structures specific to an application or utility for anomalies, and delete them.
Restrict the sources of executables and the locations in which execution can occur, or implement other constraints on execution access.
Use hidden logic to enable exfiltrated data to signal its location or embed hidden data that can be the subject of a search.
Present plausible but factitious data assets to attract the adversary. Monitor uses of those assets, or search for the presence of decoy information.
Fragment information, and distribute it across multiple locations.
Minimize local functionality, and disallow writable storage.
Dynamically move data resources.
Dynamically update an account’s authorizations or privileges.
Partition a host (e.g., server, endpoint system) into separate logical domains.
Construct or configure systems or applications to minimize their inherent functionality.
Provide an isolated communications path between the user and security functions.
Terminate processes or disable capabilities upon triggering conditions.

Determine the mission consequences of adversary activities (e.g., which resources can be relied on; how quickly, how completely, and with what confidence mission-essential services, data, and communications can be restored from backups or alternative resources).
Use one or more factitious systems or other resources to identify malicious sites, interact with the adversary, actively probe for malicious code, and observe adversary TTPs.
Minimize the lifespan or retention of data, and ensure that deleted data cannot be retrieved.
Authenticate a device before establishing a connection to it.
Use situation-specific, risk- adaptive, or out-of-band authentication.

ATT&CK Mitigation Name: Minimize Duration of Connection or Session
ATT&CK Mitigation Description: Minimize the time period for which a connection remains open or a session remains active, requiring reauthorization to reestablish connectivity.
Use multiple designs to implement the same functionality.
Ensure that policies are applied consistently across systems, applications, and services.
Validate data quality (e.g., integrity, consistency, correctness).

Maintain an internal deception environment, divert suspicious traffic to that environment, and interact with and analyze behavior to determine whether it is malicious and whether to investigate adversary TTPs.
Move and make inaccessible or delete suspicious files.

ATT&CK Mitigation Name: Isolate or Contain Selected Applications or Components
ATT&CK Mitigation Description: Isolate or contain (e.g., using internal firewalls or virtual environments) selected applications or components based on risk profiles.
Refresh software, firmware, or data from a trusted source.
Conceal (e.g., via encryption or data hiding) or remove sensitive information (including metadata).
Identify and redirect malware found on external systems.
Validate data properties (including binaries, metadata, and cryptographic bindings) to defend against modification or fabrication.
Switch to one or more alternative data sources to ensure adequate data quality or rebuild destroyed data.
Reconfigure or reallocate resources to route around damage.
Use alternative communications paths.
Reconstruct assets (e.g., files, software components) that have been damaged, destroyed, or modified in a way that makes them suspect.
Switch (failover) to a duplicate system in a protected enclave that, subject to additional quality controls on data and software updates, mirrors the system that has been compromised.

ATT&CK Mitigation Name: Switch to Alternate System or Component
ATT&CK Mitigation Description: Switch (failover) to another system or system component that provides approximately the same functionality in a different way.
Activate an alternate system or system component (e.g., from a war-time reserve) that provides approximately the same function in a novel or specialized way, and failover.
Increase sensor activity and restrict privileges to defend against an adversary taking advantage of failover or recovery activities.
Terminate and re-establish sessions or network connections unpredictably to disrupt adversary use.
Adapt to reduce the impacts of denial-of-service attacks.
Conceal (via encryption or insertion of fabricated traffic) or randomize network traffic patterns.
Restrict the visibility of or access to data based on the nature or attributes of that data.
Suspend a process and re- instantiate it in a different location.
Maintain distinct enclaves based on security characteristics, and use stringent filtering to defend the enclave boundary.
Provide defenses against attacks against system memory.
Use controlled interfaces and communication paths to provide access to risky capabilities or filter communications between enclaves.
Use hardware-based protections for firmware.
Validate information output from processes or applications against defined criteria.
Physically move resources (e.g., storage devices, servers, end-user devices) with concomitant changes to network location.
Enforce access restrictions, and provide alerting to defend against data mining.
Provide mechanisms to protect audit data from modification or observation.
Keep users, administrators, and operators aware of existing and emerging threats and attack techniques that they can counter in practice.
Protect the network addresses of system components that are part of managed interfaces from discovery through common tools and techniques, such as hiding or relocation.
Collaborate with other entities to counter adversary activities.
Limit an adversary’s ability to determine or manipulate the organization’s cyber supply chain.
Redefine the system in terms of components, interfaces, and dependencies.
Configure administrator access to resources based on active defense strategies.
Use awareness of the current threat landscape to inform threat hunting and threat-adaptive defenses.
Maintain awareness of mission dependencies and the current status of mission-critical assets to inform threat-adaptive responses.
Integrate automated and human- directed response to suspicious events to minimize disruption.
Enhance the effectiveness of defender actions by using capabilities unpredictably or by adding noise or false information to query responses.
Increase barriers to adversary effectiveness by providing architecturally diverse system components.
Restrict access to applications and configurations as part of the installation process, and narrowly restrict modifications or other uses of privileged functions.
Provide similar capabilities or mechanisms at multiple architectural layers.
Provide environments separate from the operational environment for activities with specific risks.
Maintain awareness of the vulnerability posture over time to inform the calibration of detection and proactive responses.
Provide supporting protections for distributed processing and distributed or replicated storage.
Enhance the effectiveness of or confidence in security functions via system mechanisms for isolation.
Enhance the effectiveness of or confidence in isolation by using underlying hardware features.

ATT&CK Mitigation Name: Validate or Assess Control Effectiveness in Practice
ATT&CK Mitigation Description: Validate or assess the effectiveness of controls as implemented and used in practice.
Use automation to increase the effectiveness or quality of capabilities or practices.
Maintain a reserve of critical components, both special-purpose and acquired, for use in a crisis situation.
Coordinate across the organization and with external stakeholders to increase the effectiveness or timeliness of responsive capabilities and practices.
Analyze network traffic for unusual data flows. Traffic inspection and analysis can be performed at the enterprise boundary, at internal boundaries between enclaves, or within enclaves.
Analyze the behavior of endpoint (i.e., end-user, client) systems for anomalous behavior.
Monitor system and application logs for anomalous or suspicious behavior.
Analyze logs (individually or with some correlation across logs) for anomalous or suspicious patterns of behavior.
Analyze the contents of specific files or types of files for suspicious contents.
Detect anomalous or unauthorized events on hosts (e.g., servers, endpoint systems).
Detect anomalous or unauthorized events involving the use of removable devices.
Perform integrity checks (e.g., using checksums, hashes, or digital signatures) on software, software certificates, or metadata.
Perform software stress testing (e.g., using out-of-bounds input values) prior to installation.
Perform a physical inspection of hardware components for indicators of tampering.
Monitor the behavior and status (e.g., change in ownership) of second or third parties.
Analyze user account usage across the enterprise for anomalies or suspicious behavior.
Analyze process attributes or behavior for indications of unusual, unauthorized, or suspicious use.
Monitor the behavior of processes for indications of unusual, unauthorized, or suspicious use.
Monitor activity associated with cloud accounts for indications of unusual, unauthorized, or suspicious use.
Monitor and analyze activity associated with privileged accounts for indications of unusual or suspicious use.
Correlate and analyze the behavior of multiple systems.
Scrutinize the contents and behavior patterns of an endpoint system.
Monitor and analyze events in the context of a specific application or utility.
Monitor and analyze activity associated with user accounts for indications of unusual or suspicious use.
Correlate and analyze events occurring on a single host.
Centralize instance logging in a cloud or container environment and analyze.
Monitor for the execution of scripts that are unknown or used in suspicious ways.
Monitor and analyze uses of application interfaces (APIs).
Monitor the file system to identify the unexpected presence and atypical use of specific types of files or atypical patterns of access.
Monitor specific servers for anomalous or suspicious uses or access attempts.
Monitor the use of specific files or directories for anomalous or suspicious uses or access attempts.
Monitor command line interface use for common utilities (part of the system or installed by an adversary) and suspicious behavior.

ATT&CK Mitigation Name: Monitor Use of Libraries and Utilities
ATT&CK Mitigation Description: Monitor the use of libraries and utilities that are commonly used to support adversary actions.
Analyze the contents of network traffic.
Analyze outgoing traffic for patterns of behavior that indicate adversary communications.
Monitor and analyze external information sources for indicators of adversary activities, especially those targeting the organization.
Monitor the status of platforms (e.g., user endpoints, servers, network devices).
Monitor network usage for anomalous behavior.
Hunt for applications or processes that display specific malicious or suspect behaviors.
